title: How to Use Organic Pesticides for Gardening

steps.headline: Identify which insects are pests and which insects will help your garden.
steps.description: For example, you want to attract and keep bees and ladybugs. They pollinate your flowers and eat unwanted insects. Purchase ladybugs or their larvae if these insects are not showing up in your garden on their own. You can order them from distributors online, or check with your local garden shop.

steps.headline: Set up a bird bath and a bird feeder.
steps.description: Birds are natural pesticides. They will eat the unwelcome insects in your garden, so attract them to the area. Use sunflowers to attract birds as well. If you plant them in your garden side by side like a hedge, you can also create a border around your garden to keep deer and other small animals out of your plants and flowers.

steps.headline: Install netting on your garden.
steps.description: Lightweight nets will keep insects off your plants and flowers without using any harmful chemicals. Find netting that is transparent enough to allow sunlight to reach your garden. You can find this netting at home and garden stores or in organic produce shops.

steps.headline: Handpick insects from your garden.
steps.description: Your fingers can act as an organic pesticide. Pick off visible slugs, beetles and other insects. Place the insects in a dish or bowl filled with warm soapy water to kill them. Use a stick to brush moths and bugs out of trees or from branches and leaves you cannot reach.

steps.headline: Make your own organic pesticide to apply to your garden.
steps.description: Mix petroleum oil and water in a spray bottle. Spray the solution onto plants and flowers in your garden to repel insects. EXPERT TIP																															Steve Masley																Organic Vegetable Gardener								Steve Masley has been designing and maintaining organic vegetable gardens in the San Francisco Bay Area for over 30 years. He is a Organic Gardening Consultant and Founder of Grow-It-Organically, a website that teaches clients and students the ins and outs of organic vegetable gardening. In 2007 and 2008, Steve taught the Local Sustainable Agriculture Field Practicum at Stanford University. Steve Masley			Organic Vegetable Gardener				Try soap spray to get rid of insects. Pat Browne and Steve Masley of Grow it Organically say: "Mix a teaspoon of dish soap and a teaspoon of vegetable oil in a pump spray bottle, and spray it on your plants where you see bugs. You can even add chili oil or garlic oil to the spray help prevent the bugs from coming back for a week or so."

steps.headline: Try organic pesticides that are for sale.
steps.description: You can find organic products at home and garden stores such as Lowes and Home Depot, discount department stores such as WalMart and Target, and through online retailers. Read labels. Make sure there are no chemicals or ingredients you do not recognize.

steps.headline: Follow the application instructions on the bottle.
steps.description: Most organic pesticides will be sprayed directly onto plants, leaves, trees and flowers. Try an organic pesticide that includes diatomaceous earth, which is a powder made from the fossils of sea creatures. It causes insects to dehydrate and die. Use a product that includes garlic. Garlic is a natural insecticide and fungicide and works best on fruit and vegetable plants.

text: Identify which insects are pests and which insects will help your garden. For example, you want to attract and keep bees and ladybugs. They pollinate your flowers and eat unwanted insects. Purchase ladybugs or their larvae if these insects are not showing up in your garden on their own. You can order them from distributors online, or check with your local garden shop. Set up a bird bath and a bird feeder. Birds are natural pesticides. They will eat the unwelcome insects in your garden, so attract them to the area. Use sunflowers to attract birds as well. If you plant them in your garden side by side like a hedge, you can also create a border around your garden to keep deer and other small animals out of your plants and flowers. Install netting on your garden. Lightweight nets will keep insects off your plants and flowers without using any harmful chemicals. Find netting that is transparent enough to allow sunlight to reach your garden. You can find this netting at home and garden stores or in organic produce shops. Handpick insects from your garden. Your fingers can act as an organic pesticide. Pick off visible slugs, beetles and other insects. Place the insects in a dish or bowl filled with warm soapy water to kill them. Use a stick to brush moths and bugs out of trees or from branches and leaves you cannot reach. Make your own organic pesticide to apply to your garden. Mix petroleum oil and water in a spray bottle. Spray the solution onto plants and flowers in your garden to repel insects. He is a Organic Gardening Consultant and Founder of Grow-It-Organically, a website that teaches clients and students the ins and outs of organic vegetable gardening. In 2007 and 2008, Steve taught the Local Sustainable Agriculture Field Practicum at Stanford University. Steve Masley			Organic Vegetable Gardener				Try soap spray to get rid of insects. Pat Browne and Steve Masley of Grow it Organically say: "Mix a teaspoon of dish soap and a teaspoon of vegetable oil in a pump spray bottle, and spray it on your plants where you see bugs. You can even add chili oil or garlic oil to the spray help prevent the bugs from coming back for a week or so." Try organic pesticides that are for sale. You can find organic products at home and garden stores such as Lowes and Home Depot, discount department stores such as WalMart and Target, and through online retailers. Read labels. Make sure there are no chemicals or ingredients you do not recognize. Follow the application instructions on the bottle. Most organic pesticides will be sprayed directly onto plants, leaves, trees and flowers. Try an organic pesticide that includes diatomaceous earth, which is a powder made from the fossils of sea creatures. It causes insects to dehydrate and die. Use a product that includes garlic. Garlic is a natural insecticide and fungicide and works best on fruit and vegetable plants.

For example, you want to attract and keep bees and ladybugs.
They pollinate your flowers and eat unwanted insects.
Purchase ladybugs or their larvae if these insects are not showing up in your garden on their own.
You can order them from distributors online, or check with your local garden shop.
Set up a bird bath and a bird feeder.
Birds are natural pesticides.
They will eat the unwelcome insects in your garden, so attract them to the area.
Use sunflowers to attract birds as well.
If you plant them in your garden side by side like a hedge, you can also create a border around your garden to keep deer and other small animals out of your plants and flowers.
Install netting on your garden.
Lightweight nets will keep insects off your plants and flowers without using any harmful chemicals.
Find netting that is transparent enough to allow sunlight to reach your garden.
You can find this netting at home and garden stores or in organic produce shops.
Handpick insects from your garden.
Your fingers can act as an organic pesticide.
Pick off visible slugs, beetles and other insects.
Place the insects in a dish or bowl filled with warm soapy water to kill them.
Use a stick to brush moths and bugs out of trees or from branches and leaves you cannot reach.
Make your own organic pesticide to apply to your garden.
Mix petroleum oil and water in a spray bottle.
Spray the solution onto plants and flowers in your garden to repel insects.

You can even add chili oil or garlic oil to the spray help prevent the bugs from coming back for a week or so."

You can find organic products at home and garden stores such as Lowes and Home Depot, discount department stores such as WalMart and Target, and through online retailers.
Read labels.
Make sure there are no chemicals or ingredients you do not recognize.

Most organic pesticides will be sprayed directly onto plants, leaves, trees and flowers.
Try an organic pesticide that includes diatomaceous earth, which is a powder made from the fossils of sea creatures.
It causes insects to dehydrate and die.
Use a product that includes garlic.
Garlic is a natural insecticide and fungicide and works best on fruit and vegetable plants.
